section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Norman Bridwell
section-block.rac_book_summary: Emily Elizabeth has taught Clifford how to have good manners. That’s one reason everyone loves him! What can Clifford teach you about good manners?

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64280-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1987 by Norman Bridwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_body-text: Use Aa and Bb Alphabet Cards.Show all the pictures. Say: A is for apple. I spy an apple. Who can show me what I spy? Continue. Now show all the letters and play “I Spy.”
Sing this to the tune “Mary Had a Little Lamb”: “Will you be a friend of mine, friend of mine, friend of mine? Will you be a friend of mine, And __ around with me?” (hop, wiggle...)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we will read Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. He wrote the words and drew the pictures in this book.
Pablo loves books about Clifford! He’s such a good friend.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
What good manners does Clifford have?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do you love Clifford? Who can ask for something using good manners, like Clifford?
Why does Clifford write a thank-you note?
I see two words on this page that begin with the letter b. Who can point to the words?
Let’s trace the letter b in the air with a finger.
Who does Clifford share his toys with?
Clifford washes his hands before he eats. Raise your hand if you wash your hands before eating. Why is this a good thing to do?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What good manners does Clifford have?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He shares his toys with his friends.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about having good manners when playing with friends.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is it important to have good manners?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Just as we teach children good manners, we must teach them good hygiene habits. Starting young helps build a foundation that will grow with children. Incorporating specific times to wash hands throughout the school day (before snack and lunch, after using the bathroom) will go far in preventing the spread of germs from child to child.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Empathy
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a discussion about noticing how someone else feels and if they needs help. Ask children to imagine a friend hurt their knee. What could you do to help? What if a friend is sad because they lost their hat? How could you help? Explain that we can show empathy by noticing how someone feels and helping if we can. When we help others feel good, we feel good, too.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and see how Clifford shows he cares as we revisit Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell.
Clifford loves this book because it shows how he understands the feelings of others. He uses good manners even when he has a problem with a friend.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Clifford points to his food. What does he say to ask for it politely? Who can politely ask to borrow my pencil?
Why does Clifford say, “Excuse me”? Who can remember another time to use good manners and say “Excuse me”?
Why is it important to follow the rules of a game? Why isn’t it fun to play a game with someone who doesn’t follow the rules? (MB)
Clifford disagrees with Mary Elizabeth. Why is it okay to disagree? What can you do instead of getting angry when you lose? (MB)
What does Clifford do when he meets his sister’s friend? Pretend you don’t know your neighbor. Turn and shake hands politely.

section.rac_body-text: Before you play, hide a small scarf for a toy bear, a ruler, and other small objects. Invite children to sit in a circle. Tell these stories:

1. Bear (a stuffed toy) lost her best scarf. How does she feel? What can we do to help her? Invite children to go on a hunt to find the scarf. When the scarf is found, invite children to tell why it feels good to make Bear feel better.

2. Bear broke her ruler. How does she feel? What can we do to help her? Invite children to go on a hunt to find a ruler that is not broken. When the ruler is found, invite children to tell why it feels good to make Bear feel better.
Continue with other stories. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about solving problems with good manners.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Scientific studies show that teaching kindness benefits growing children emotionally and physically. It helps them to develop into happy adults. According to Patty O’Grady, PhD, the best way for children to learn to be kind is to feel it themselves. Benefits of teaching kindness in school: increased peer acceptance, sense of belonging, improved self-esteem.

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss how strong readers use story clues and what they know to make a guess in a story. Share the Make an Inference strategy card.
If you want to be a friend, clap your hands (clap 2x)/ (Repeat) A friend is someone who, is always kind to you./If you want to be a friend, clap your hands (clap 2x). “hooray,” etc.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell.
This book teaches us good lessons. Pablo likes Clifford because he learns things even though Clifford isn’t a real dog.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
When does Clifford use good manners?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When does Clifford say “please” and “thank you”? Tap your nose if you will remember to say “please” and “thank you.”

The author doesn’t explain why we shouldn’t talk during a movie. Let’s use story clues and what we already know to make a smart guess about it. Look at the illustration. What clues can you find? Now think about a time you couldn’t hear me reading a story because someone was talking. How did you feel?
Clifford shares his toys with his friends. What happens when you share with your friends? How does it make you feel when a friend does not share a toy with you?
Clifford calls ahead when he visits his sister. What does that mean? Why is it good manners?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s use those guesses as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
When does Clifford use good manners?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: When he is at the movies.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to talk and write about behaviors that show good manners.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Clifford call before he visits?
Which good manners would Clifford use in a school?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Most adults begin teaching their children good manners early in life. Many people simply model appropriate language and behaviors. Manners are important in all interactions, making it essential for getting along with others. Learning good manners early builds good habits and gives children advantages in many areas of life.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about being a good friend. What are some good manners friends have with each other? What can friends do if they don’t agree about something?
Imagine you do not know your neighbor. Turn to your neighbor and shake hands and introduce yourself. Say: Hi, my name is Jon. Won’t you be my friend?
Introduce new vocabulary that will be helpful to children as they continue to talk about friends.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a story about two friends, Alisha and Rico. This poster gives us information that can help us be good friends.
Pablo can’t wait to read about children who are good friends!
Clifford’s Manners and “Thank You, Friend!” are both about how we can be a good friend.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about the concept question:
How can we be a good friend to others?
section.rac_body-text: Share the poster with children. Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then, use these prompts to read and discuss the poster.
Use the Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends like to do things together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who are the boys pretending to be? What do you like to do with a friend?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends share and take turns.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Good friends take turns on the swing? What if two friends each want to be first? How can they solve the problem?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Good friends do nice things for each other.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the girls doing together?
Who can point to the words below each picture? Which two words are the same for all three pictures? How can the children show good manners like Clifford?

section.rac_body-text: Have the group sit in a circle. Explain that you will name one way someone in each group is a good friend. Then you will toss the beanbag (or ball) to someone else in the circle. Then it’s that child’s turn to say something nice about a different friend in the circle. For example, “Sarah is a good friend because she helps me put away books.” Then toss the ball to Sarah.
Provide a writing prompt about being a good friend. Give support as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children are naturally egocentric. They need to be taught conflict-resolution skills. When conflicts arise, adults step in and resolve the conflict. Instead teach conflict-resolution strategies: Use a calm voice, listen to all sides, encourage children to suggest solutions and choose one to try out. Discuss differences in outcome based on the solution chosen.

section-block.rac_body-text: Let’s sing a song about friendship! I will choose someone to go around the circle with me as we sing. When I stop, I will tell a friend one way they are a good friend. Then they will take a turn choosing someone to go around the circle. (Tune: Mary Had a Little Lamb) [Sam] is a good friend of mine, friend of mine, friend of mine, [Sam] is a good friend of mine and this is how I know. [child adds reason]
Review these vocabulary words that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out the book Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell.
This book gives us information that helps us learn things. Pablo loves to learn about new things.
This week, we read about how Clifford uses his good manners wherever he goes. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
How do you show you have good manners?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell scenes from the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When does Clifford say “please”? Who can show me how you use the word “please” to ask for something?
Who remembers what Clifford does when someone gives him a present?
Clifford does not like litterbugs! Let’s take a few minutes to clean up any litter off the floor.
Who remembers what manners Clifford uses with his toys when he is with his friends?
Let’s pretend we’re playing tennis like Clifford and Emily Elizabeth. Turn to your neighbor and show how to be a good sport.
Who can retell some of the manners Clifford uses while he visits his sister? Act out each example as you tell about it.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you show you have good manners?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about being a good friend. Assist with words as needed. Allow children to share their work with classmates, and tell why they like to be a good friend to others.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does someone with good manners share?
How do you feel when you use good manners?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Not all social codes are the same across cultures, so it’s important to keep that in mind when teaching concepts such as manners to children from various cultures. Take time to learn about the social norms in cultures represented by your multilingual learners.
